ETYMOLOGY: From Middle English 'flawe' (a fragment, flake, crack), from Old Norse 'flaga' (a flake, chip, slab), related to 'flagna' (to break up).
SINCE: Late 14th century (as a noun), early 17th century (as a verb)

MEANINGS.PATTERN: a flaw in [sth] | [sth] has a flaw
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A slight imperfection or defect which mars or spoils the appearance or completeness of something.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 使某物的外观或完整性受损的轻微缺陷或不足。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The only flaw in his argument was a reliance on outdated data.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他论点中唯一的缺陷是对过时数据的依赖。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To make a fault or defect in something; to mar or spoil.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 使某物产生缺点或缺陷；损坏或破坏。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: A small error can flaw an entire scientific experiment.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 一个小的错误可能毁掉整个科学实验。
